video.title: UI / UX Design Tutorial – Wireframe, Mockup & Design in Figma
video.description:
Learn the process of UI / UX design.  In this tutorial you will learn how a professional designer builds a full website design from scratch following the process of user experience and user interface. The video covers wireframing, prototyping, and designing in Figma.

This course was developed by Adrian Twarog. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvM5YYWwfLwpcQgbRr68JLQ

⭐️ Sections ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (01:27) Wireframing
⌨️ (30:58) UI Layout
⌨️ (1:06:38) Mockup

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Misha Kerch
topLevelComment.text:
This video needs updating.
There was no use of the Auto-layout feature, design system, styles, row grid, etc.
There is no responsive design system. No logical system was used for margining and aligning. Everything is a mess. It's fine if it's just a sketch, but even then I want proper spacing and alignment, and Auto-layout can handle that beautifully. There is also no use of components. A FREE icon plugin could have been used when searching for icons in the app.

replies.author: nr
replies.text: @Animanga dude np, its a super collabrative job. Youre talking ALL OF THE TIME. One of the appeals to tech-jobs for most of us introverts is to be able to sorta avoid people, but this job is NOT that. Luckily I'm pretty extrovert but the constant meetings and back and forth on product design can reaaaalllyy get on your nerves if you're someone who just wants to go auto-pilot and work. If you're not really a social butterfly or get annoyed by peoples "criticisms" (most of the time they just nit-pick because they prefer their own design lol because they want credit).  This is something I really never was told, I was just sold on the creative aspect like most people are but the actual "creative freedom" doesn't exist unless you're working for a small company or freelanced.

replies.author: Animanga
replies.text: Thanks for warnings bro

replies.author: nr
replies.text: No. Take a coding job if youre average. UX will push you out of your comfort zone everyday, it's very demanding. From constant call-meetings to debating designs and feedback, not to mention the job functionality itself. If you're content with being average and just want a paycheck, this job will stress you out.

topLevelComment.author: NoFavors

topLevelComment.author: Beryl Pretorius
topLevelComment.text:
He used CONCEPTS to create the wireframe

You can use CTRL+C, CTRL+D or ALT+left click drag to copy items

This does NOT encompass the entire UX process, however it does provide a solid FOUNDATION for those just starting out

Leave the man alone to intro his videos the way he wants

There are many ads because they need revenue somehow to make a living off providing otherwise FREE learning resources

There is no such thing as Figma VS XD - everyone has their own preference

No, you don't need to learn UI/UX to be a front end dev, however it does certainly help

He made a mistake about not uploading his own sketch, however you will benefit far more by creating original content instead of just copying his

topLevelComment.text: How is he copy pasting

replies.author: Beryl Pretorius
replies.text:
There are a few different ways:
1. CTRL+C on the item you want to copy, then CTRL+V to paste it.
2. Hold ALT & left click drag an object to copy it and place it elsewhere.
3. Select the object you want to copy and press CTRL+D to duplicate.

If you are looking for tutorials about Figma, this video isn't for you. This video is more like a UI / UX tutorial and Figma is only used as a tool for that purpose, at a VERY BASIC level in this video.

However, if you find a video to learn about UI/UX quickly and in practice so you can apply it to your project immediately, this is very suitable for you.

replies.author: DestroyOnLoad
replies.text: @Piyush Mahapatra look up Vako Shvili's course on Udemy.  It goes from design fundamentals -> Figma -> Webflow -> Freelancing.  It's a huge start.  After that course I started making components with HTML and CSS that I thought were interesting and save for a later project.  I do that daily.  Just remember, front-end sells but people ALWAYS need help with the back-end.  There's plenty of work to do being a full stack dev that has an eye for design.
